item.title: There's An Amazing New Drug For Multiple Sclerosis. Should I Try It?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Beam Me Up, Scotty ... Sort Of. Chinese Scientists 'Teleport' Photon To Space
item.description:
July 14, 2017 - Chinese scientists have announced they pulled off a successful teleportation of a photon from Earth to space. But what does that really mean?
- http://www.npr.org/2017/07/14/537174817/scientists-teleport-a-photon-into-space
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 14, 2017 - Chinese scientists have announced they pulled off a successful teleportation of a photon from Earth to space. But what does that really mean? http://www.npr.org/2017/07/14/537174817/scientists-teleport-a-photon-into-space

item.title: Ravens Surprise Scientists By Showing They Can Plan
item.description: July 13, 2017 - As recently as 10 years ago, humans were thought to be the only species with the ability to plan. Turns out ravens can, too, on a par with great apes.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - As recently as 10 years ago, humans were thought to be the only species with the ability to plan. Turns out ravens can, too, on a par with great apes. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/07/13/537040868/ravens-surprise-scientists-by-showing-they-can-plan

item.title: If It Walks Like An Ant, You Probably Wouldn't Eat It â€” Or So These Spiders Hope
item.description: July 13, 2017 - A scientist discovers how some spiders go undercover as a less delicious species to evade predators.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - A scientist discovers how some spiders go undercover as a less delicious species to evade predators. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/07/13/537081375/if-it-walks-like-an-ant-you-probably-wouldnt-eat-it-or-so-these-spiders-hope

item.title: Scientists Discover Sneaky Spider That Fools Predators
item.description: July 13, 2017 - It's a dog eat dog world out there in nature. One way not to get eaten is to look like something else that's not tasty. Now scientists have discovered a spider that fools predators by not only looking like a nasty ant, but actually walking like one.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - It's a dog eat dog world out there in nature. One way not to get eaten is to look like something else that's not tasty. Now scientists have discovered a spider that fools predators by not only looking like a nasty ant, but actually walking like one. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/13/537082136/scientists-discover-sneaky-spider-that-fools-predators

item.title: Afghan Girls Robotics Team Allowed To Enter U.S. For Competition
item.description: July 13, 2017 - President Trump intervened to find a way to permit the girls entry after their applications for visas were twice rejected. For the budding scientists, the path to compete has been a long one.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - President Trump intervened to find a way to permit the girls entry after their applications for visas were twice rejected. item.title: How Storytelling Can Improve The Care Of People With Alzheimer's
item.description:
July 13, 2017 - A former journalist is making sure caregivers know patients' life stories.
- http://the1a.org/shows/2017-07-13/memory-well
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - A former journalist is making sure caregivers know patients' life stories. http://the1a.org/shows/2017-07-13/memory-well

item.title: No Offense, American Bees, But Your Sperm Isn't Cutting It
item.description: July 13, 2017 - U.S. bees are in trouble, and one of the major threats is a deadly parasite called varroa mite. So researchers are importing sperm from European bees resistant to mites to toughen up America's stock.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - U.S. bees are in trouble, and one of the major threats is a deadly parasite called varroa mite. So researchers are importing sperm from European bees resistant to mites to toughen up America's stock. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/07/13/536884827/no-offense-american-bees-but-your-sperm-isnt-cutting-it

item.title: 'Living Drug' That Fights Cancer By Harnessing Immune System Clears Key Hurdle
item.description: July 12, 2017 - An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration recommends the agency, for the first time, approve a new kind of treatment that uses genetically modified immune cells to attack cancer cells.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration recommends the agency, for the first time, approve a new kind of treatment that uses genetically modified immune cells to attack cancer cells. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/12/536812206/living-drug-that-fights-cancer-by-harnessing-the-immune-system-clears-key-hurdle

item.title: Statue Of Scopes Trial Lawyer Sparks Debate In Tennessee
item.description: July 12, 2017 - In 1925, the Scopes Trial sparked national debates about creationism and secularism, and put Dayton, Tenn., on the map. Now another debate is happening in Dayton about whether it's appropriate to memorialize the secular side with a statue.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - In 1925, the Scopes Trial sparked national debates about creationism and secularism, and put Dayton, Tenn., on the map. Now another debate is happening in Dayton about whether it's appropriate to memorialize the secular side with a statue. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/12/536887930/statue-of-scopes-trial-lawyer-sparks-debate-in-tennessee

item.title: More People Are Making Mistakes With Medicines At Home
item.description: July 12, 2017 - A study analyzing data from poison control centers finds that the rate of serious medication errors outside health care settings doubled between 2000 and 2012.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - A study analyzing data from poison control centers finds that the rate of serious medication errors outside health care settings doubled between 2000 and 2012. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/12/536519077/took-the-wrong-medicine-by-mistake-study-finds-such-errors-are-on-the-rise

item.title: Massive Iceberg Breaks Free In Antarctica
item.description: July 12, 2017 - Scientists say the iceberg is one of the largest seen by satellites. But the full implications of its separation off remain to be seen.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - Scientists say the iceberg is one of the largest seen by satellites. But the full implications of its separation off remain to be seen. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/07/12/536818782/massive-iceberg-breaks-free-in-antarctica

item.title: Video: Japan Created Easy-To-Swallow Foods To Prevent Senior Choking Deaths
item.description: July 12, 2017 - In NPR's Elise Tries series, correspondent Elise Hu tries out different experiences in East Asia. In rapidly aging Japan, an edible innovation is helping seniors enjoy meals without fear of choking.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - In NPR's Elise Tries series, correspondent Elise Hu tries out different experiences in East Asia. In rapidly aging Japan, an edible innovation is helping seniors enjoy meals without fear of choking. http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/07/12/532716164/video-japan-created-easy-to-swallow-foods-to-prevent-senior-choking-deaths

item.title: Macron Got A Lot Wrong About Africa ... But Made One Good Point
item.description: July 11, 2017 - In answering a reporter's question, the French president characterized Africa as a continent of failing states with high birth rates. Viviane Rutabingwa shares her perspective.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 11, 2017 - In answering a reporter's question, the French president characterized Africa as a continent of failing states with high birth rates. Viviane Rutabingwa shares her perspective. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/07/11/536445457/macron-got-a-lot-wrong-about-africa-but-made-one-good-point

item.title: Web Comic: The Scientist Who Escaped Aleppo
item.description:
July 11, 2017 - It was a harrowing journey. Nedal Said made a new life in Germany â€” and found what he'd always been looking for.
